steps.title: Choose small to medium turnips for freezing.
steps.content: Choose small to medium turnips for freezing. Larger turnips are tougher and can have a stronger flavor that makes them unappealing when you take them out of storage. Look for small or medium-sized turnips and give them a good squeeze to make sure they’re tender. [1] X Trustworthy Source National Center for Home Food Preservation Publicly-funded center dedicated to educating consumers about research-backed safety practices for preserving food Go to source Large turnips are better for storing in your fridge unpeeled in an unsealed plastic bag and will last for up to a month. [2] X Research source Smaller turnips are usually younger, making them more tender.

steps.title: Rinse the turnips and scrub off any dirt from their surface.
steps.content: Rinse the turnips and scrub off any dirt from their surface. Run all of the turnips beneath a faucet to give them a good rinsing. As you rinse them, use your fingers to scrub off dirt and residue that may be stuck on the surface. [3] X Research source Removing dirt helps reduce potential contaminants that could cause the turnips to spoil more quickly.

steps.title: Peel the skin off of the turnips with a vegetable peeler.
steps.content: Peel the skin off of the turnips with a vegetable peeler. Hold 1 turnip in your hand with a firm grip so it doesn’t slip out. Take a vegetable peeler and run it over the surface of the turnips to strip off the peel. Peel all of the turnips so the nice and tender inner flesh is exposed. Discard the peels or keep the collected peels to boil and make a vegetable stock with them!

steps.title: Dice the turnips into 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) cubes with a knife.
steps.content: Dice the turnips into 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) cubes with a knife. Place the freshly peeled turnips onto a cutting board or cutting surface. Take a kitchen knife or a sharp paring knife and cut them up into cubes about 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) in size so they blanch evenly. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add the cubes to boiling water for 2 minutes to blanch them.
steps.content: Add the cubes to boiling water for 2 minutes to blanch them. Fill a pot with water and bring it to a rolling boil on the stove. Once the water is boiling, carefully add the turnips into the pot and set a timer for 2 minutes. [5] X Research source Blanching is critical to stop enzymes from causing the turnips to lose their flavor, color, and texture, making them perfect for freezing. It’s not meant to cook them. [6] X Trustworthy Source National Center for Home Food Preservation Publicly-funded center dedicated to educating consumers about research-backed safety practices for preserving food Go to source The turnips will be sterilized as well, which makes them keep longer in storage.

steps.title: Transfer the turnips to a bowl of ice water to cool them.
steps.content: Transfer the turnips to a bowl of ice water to cool them. Fill a bowl with clean water and add some ice cubes to it to help bring down the temperature. Use a strainer or a spoon to scoop out the blanched turnips and add them into the bowl to stop them from cooking any further. [7] X Research source You could also drain the hot water from the pot and then dump the turnips into the bowl of ice water.

steps.title: Drain the water once the turnips are cool to the touch.
steps.content: Drain the water once the turnips are cool to the touch. Wait about 2-3 minutes and then reach into the water to touch the turnips. If they’re cool to the touch and don’t feel warm at all, then they’re done cooking and good to go. Drain the water out of the bowl into a sink. [8] X Trustworthy Source National Center for Home Food Preservation Publicly-funded center dedicated to educating consumers about research-backed safety practices for preserving food Go to source You could use a strainer or simply cover the bowl and pour out the water. If the turnips are still warm, just wait another minute or so. It’s really important that they’re fully cooled and don’t cook any further before you store them so they keep their texture, flavor, and color.

steps.title: Place the turnips into freezer bags, leaving 1⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of headspace.
steps.content: Place the turnips into freezer bags, leaving 1 ⁄ 2 inch (1.3 cm) of headspace. Use a plastic freezer bag that’s designed to store food. Add the turnips into the bag, but leave a small amount of space at the top of the bag to allow you to press out air and allow the turnips to freeze evenly and consistently. [9] X Trustworthy Source National Center for Home Food Preservation Publicly-funded center dedicated to educating consumers about research-backed safety practices for preserving food Go to source

steps.title: Remove the air from the bag and seal it.
steps.content: Remove the air from the bag and seal it. Seal the bag almost all of the way, leaving a small gap at 1 end. Use your hands to squeeze the bag and press out as much air as you can. Then, seal the end of the bag so it’s fully closed. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Date the bag and store the turnips in your freezer for up to 10 months.
steps.content: Date the bag and store the turnips in your freezer for up to 10 months. Take a marker and write the date on the outside of the bag so you’ll remember exactly when you stored the turnips. Place the bag in your freezer and they’re good to go for at least 10 months. Always check the date before you use them. [11] X Research source The turnips may actually keep even longer. Inspect them and make sure they don’t look or smell rotten before you use them.
